climbs.name: Common Knowledge (South Pillar of False Summit)
climbs.fa: Shaun Neufeld, Drew Brayshaw, 2006 with 2 variant pitches in 2005

content.description:
There are two variant starts. The right-hand 2-pitch start (2005) climbs a 5.8 series of left-angling ramps, then a long right-facing corner and dyke system that goes from fists to fingers, with a crux at the end (5.11-) to a ledge. The left-hand (2006) start climbs a 5.9 wide crack and ledge system, then a 35 m finger crack (5.11/11+?) past the perched "Caulk Boot Flake" to the same ledge. From here, the pitches are 3) 5.10 offwidth, 4) 5.10 headwall crack, fingers to chimney; 5) 5.8 ramps; 6) scramble (4th class) to the W-notch. Â 

From the normal West Ridge hiking trail, gain the lower West Ridge shoulder, then follow an inobvious ramp down into the basin south of the peak. Climb up the center of the south buttress of the false summit from there.
Full rack including doubles to triples of finger size cams and at least one 4" and one 4.5" cam.

The long, sharp arete rising out of Centre Creek. Getting on the route is probably the crux. The start begins to the left of the NE ridge dyke start across the basin. The climb breaks down into thirds. The first third is steep and somewhat bushy; traverse left from the start of the climb and up slabs and vegetated corners. This includes the crux 5.7 pitch up a blocky corner with small trees. The first section ends at a prominent break in the ridge where the angle decreases. The mid-section is a long ramble of 2nd to 3rd class scrambling over grass and boulders with awesome exposure and ends at a sharp gendarme called the "flame-like pinnacle". From here, move across slabs from corner to corner, just right of the ridge crest, for a couple of pitches of quality rock up to around 5.4 to reach the broken summit terrain.

Cross Centre Creek doirectly (on a log if possible) and take the bushy, blocky gully angling up towards the basin below Pillar of Pi and Rexford South peak. When you reach the toe of the East Buttress, move to climber's right (north) and circle under the toe of the buttress towards the mouth of the basin between the Ne and E ridges. The start is not obvious so use the dyke on the NE ridge to orient yourself.
Full trad rack to 3". The low-angle ridge crest holds snow well into July so come prepared

climbs.name: North Face Couloir
climbs.fa: Drew Brayshaw, Shaun Neufeld, Maxim de Jong, 2012

content.description:
From Centre Creek logging road, cross the creek and follow the gully (hopefully snowfilled) into the basin with the pocket glacier below Nesakwatch Spires. Cross a tricky bergschrund and continue up the Priest-Coupe couloir between Rexford and South Nesakwatch Spire. About 80 m below the top of the couloir, break left and climb a narrow slot/chimney for a pitch, then move left on ice bulges and follow a slightly wider, open snow runnel to join the upper NE ridge about 70 m from the summit.

North face, best gained from Centre Creek
A light rock rack (nuts and tricams with one or two cams to 1.5") and a picket or two is ideal. Maybe one or two ice screws.

climbs.name: Northeast Ridge
climbs.fa: Hugh Burton, John Burton, Colin Oloman, Steve Saba, 1969

content.description:
The long, prominent ridge dividing the north and east faces, to the right (north) of the shorter and steeper east ridge.
The most common approach is as per the east ridge to the mouth of the basin between them, then up the prominent inset basalt dyke on the south side of the ridge, across from the east ridge start, to gain the crest. The original ascent climbed 5th class brush from near the toe. An ascent via steeper rock on the north side has also been used.
The ridge holds snow very late in the year so you should expect a mountaineering climb rather than an all-rock scramble under most conditions.
Once on the ridge crest, 3rd to low-5th climbing leads upwards with no real cruxes to the summit. It's a long way to go if you pitch it out, or a couple hours of fun movement if travelling ropeless.
This route is sometimes downclimbed to regain Centre Creek after climbing the more difficult East Ridge. Even if soloing, expect a long day round trip (12 hrs+) if going this way.

From Centre Creek logging road, cross the creek on a log and pick your way through bush to follow the gully up into the basin below pillar of Pi, as per the East Ridge. Cross under the toe of the east ridge on sloping slabs to gain the NE ridge dyke start.
A few pieces of passive pro (nuts and a hex/tricam or two) are probably more than enough.

The easiest route up Rexford, but not as aesthetic or popular as the others, and only really ever climbed by people who don't feel capable of doing the West Ridge or people who end up on the south side for other reasons. From the basin below Nesakwatch Spires, cross the West Ridge's toe and drop down a ramp into the basin between Rexford and the Southeast Peak (same approach as for Common Knowledge). This basin can also be reached directly by bushwacking straight uphill through old growth and bluffs from a spot on the Nesakwatch Creek FSR a couple km south of the standard Rexford trail.

From the basin climb a little way up the couloir/gully that splits the south face, right of the Common Knowledge pillar. Traverse out of that gully right on the first major ledge, and cross two small ribs to gain a rubble ramp (junction with SE couloir route) rising to the summit. Follow that easily to the summit. Descend the same way. If climbing in a group, don't knock rocks on others in your party.



See photo

Scrambling. Bring a helmet.

Climb snow and/or talus from Centre Creek road into the basin below Pillar of Pi on the east side, between the main summit of Rexford and the Southeast Peak. Continue up steepening snow in a narrow couloir to reach the sharp notch between the two peaks. From the notch ascend snow patches and easy rock on the west side of the southeast ridge to reach Rexford's summit from the east.



Pretty damn obvious from Center Creek road

Snow gear. Possibly impassible or unpleasant once snow is gone.

Fun climbing along the ridge, a couple fourth class moves and then two short pitches to a false summit, walk around the corner to the left (exposed) and one final chimmney pitch to the summit. 
  
 3 rappels down (all pitches are short enough for 60 m to be fine) and then we did one final rappel from ridge down to final talus slope because of a few steep moves.

Single rack

Across the valley from Mount Slesse. Rexford and the Nesakwatch Spires are accessed by a short steep trail from the Nesakwatch Creek FSR or by longer routes from the Centre Creek side.. The summit ridge is composed of clean, fractured granite giving excellent rock climbing.
